theory.title: The 21-Day Theory
theory.subtitle: Discover the science behind habit formation and how you can transform your life in just 21 days.

main.title: What is the 21-Day Theory?
main.description: The 21-day theory suggests that it takes approximately 21 days of consistent practice to form a new habit. This idea is based on the brain's neuroplasticity and its ability to create new neural connections through repetition.
main.quote: "Habits are the foundation of success. What you do repeatedly determines who you become."

neuroplasticity.title: Neuroplasticity
neuroplasticity.description: The brain can reorganize and form new neural connections at any age.

repetition.title: Repetition
repetition.description: Consistent practice strengthens neural pathways, making behaviors become automatic.

automation.title: Automation
automation.description: After 21 days, the behavior requires less conscious effort and becomes a habit.

consistency.title: Maintain Consistency
consistency.description: Perform your habit every day, without exceptions. Consistency is key to success.

specific.title: Be Specific
specific.description: Clearly define what you will do, when, and where. Specific habits are easier to follow.

gradual.title: Start Gradually
gradual.description: Begin with small versions of your habit. It's better to do something small consistently than something big sporadically.

environment.title: Prepare Your Environment
environment.description: Modify your environment to make it easier to perform your habit and harder to avoid it.

study1.title: Dr. Maxwell Maltz - Psycho-Cybernetics (1960)
study1.description: The origin of the 21-day theory, based on observations of plastic surgery patients.

study2.title: Dr. Phillippa Lally - University College London (2009)
study2.description: Study that found it takes an average of 66 days to form a habit, ranging from 18 to 254 days.

study3.title: Neuroplasticity Research
study3.description: Modern studies confirm that the brain can change and adapt through repeated practice.
